revisions.rev:
{{Infobox person |name = Marshall Strabala |image = Marshall Strabala April 2010 in Shanghai.jpg |image_size = |caption = Marshall Strabala views Shanghai Tower model with Shanghai skyline in background (2010) |nationality = [[United States|American]] |birth_place = [[Seattle]], Washington [[United States|U.S.]] |alma_mater = [[Harvard University]]
[[University of California at Los Angeles]]{{cite news| url=http://www.constructionnews.net/pdf_download.lasso?file=200901_HO.pdf#page=22 |title=Industry Folks: Marshall Strabala, Gensler|newspaper=Houston Construction News|page=22 | date=January 2009 |accessdate=2011-05-21}} |notable_works = [[Shanghai Tower]], [[Houston Ballet Center for Dance]], [[Hess Tower]] |organization = 2DEFINE Architecture |awards = Chicago Architecture Clubâs Burnham Prize, 1996;
AIA Chicago Chapter Grand Projects Award;
Affiliated Fellow (1997), [[American Academy in Rome]]{{cite news|newspaper=Society of Fellows News|publisher=American Academy in Rome |url=http://www.sof-aarome.org/newsletters/SOFNewsSpring09.pdf |title= SOF News, 1990s | date= spring 2009| page=15 |accessdate=2011-05-20}}}} '''Jay Marshall Strabala''' is an [[United States|American]] [[architect]] who has been recognized with participating in the design of notable buildings, including as a member of the team that designed the [[Burj Khalifa]], the [[List of tallest buildings in the world|world's tallest building]], in [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]]. However, in June 2011, two of Strabala's former architectural firm employers sued him alleging that he had "misrepresented" the role he played in various projects. == Education == Strabala received his [[bachelor of arts]] in design from the [[University of California, Los Angeles]]. In 1988, Strabala graduated with an [[Master of Architecture]] from [[Harvard Graduate School of Design]]. ==Career== ===Skidmore, Owings and Merrill=== After graduating with his master's degree, Strabala worked at [[Skidmore, Owings and Merrill]] (SOM) in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], for 19 years. He ultimately was made an associate partner in charge of design. While at SOM, Strabala served as the studio head under lead architect [[Adrian Smith (architect)|Adrian Smith]] in working on the design of [[Burj Khalifa]] ([[Dubai]], 2009), which is the tallest building in the world.{{cite journal|url=http://www.architectmagazine.com/Architects/adrian-smith-leaves-som.aspx | title=Adrian Smith Leaves SOM | author=Keegan, Edward | journal=[[Architect (magazine)|Architect]]|publisher=[[American Institute of Architects]] & [[Hanley Wood]]|date=October 2006|accessdate=2011-05-31}}{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/13/travel/13iht-tall.1.15201567.html|newspaper=[[New York Times]]|title=Rising in Dubai: Adrian Smith's vision of green: Tall and getting taller | author=Bernstein, Fred A. |date=August 12, 2008|accessdate=2011-05-31}} Strabala also worked under Smith as one of the two studio heads over the course of the project in designing the 828 m. tall [[Nanjing Greenland Financial Center]] ([[Nanjing]], China, 2010).{{cite journal|journal=that's Shanghai| issn=1672-8033 |title=The architect's architect | publisher= Urbanatomy Media | date= March 18, 2011 | url=http://www.urbanatomy.com/index.php/article/detail/115/the-architects-architect | accessdate=2011-06-03}} Also while at SOM, Strabala participated in the design of the [[Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre]] ([[Hong Kong]], 1997). Strabala left SOM in 2006. In a 2007 interview, Adrian Smith alleged that Strabala was one of several architects up for, but who did not make, partner at SOM in what Smith described as "a power move by the New York office."{{cite journal|journal=[[Metropolis (architecture magazine)|Metropolis]]|title=Parting Company| date=January 2007| volume=26|issue=6| author=Makovsky, Paul|issn=0279-4977|url=http://www.metropolismag.com/story/20070110/parting-company | accessdate=2011-06-04}} ===Gensler=== [[File:HoustonBalletApril92011.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Houston Ballet Center for Dance]]]] After leaving SOM, Strabala joined the [[Houston]], Texas, office of [[Gensler]] global architectural firm as the firm's South Central Region Director of Design in 2006.{{cite web|title=J. Marshall Strabala Joins Gensler Houston As Director Of Design | author=Gensler |publisher=officenewswire| date=April 7, 2006|url=http://www.officenewswire.com/1642 |accessdate=2011-05-21}} Strabala has been reported to have led the design of the 128-story [[Shanghai Tower]] while at Gensler and to have completed the "bulk of the design work". Gensler, however, claims that the tower is not Strabala's design. According to Gensler, "Gensler, not (Strabala), is the source of the architectural and design services rendered in designing the Shanghai Tower."{{cite journal|journal=[[Architect (magazine)|Architect]] | title=Newswire: Gensler vs. Strabala |date=June 10, 2011|publisher=American Institute of Architects & Hanley Wood|url=http://www.architectmagazine.com/architect-newswire/gensler-vs--strabala.aspx | accessdate=2011-08-07}} When it is finished, the tower will become China's tallest building and the world's second-tallest building.{{cite journal|author=Miller, JFK | url=http://www.webcitation.org/5z2JByeF2 |title=The Master Builder| journal=[[that's Shanghai]] | publisher=Urbanatomy Media|issn=1672-8033| date=December 9, 2010 | accessdate=2011-06-04|location=Shanghai, China}} Strabala also has been credited for leading Gensler's efforts in designing [[Hess Tower]] (Houston, 2010) and the [[Houston Ballet Center for Dance]] (2011).{{cite journal|date=September 26, 2010 | author=Hall, Christine|work=Houston Business Journal | title=Marshall Strabala Gives New Meaning to Supertall| accessdate=2011-06-09| url=http://www.bizjournals.com/houston/stories/2010/09/27/newscolumn2.html}}{{cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/headline/features/6556005.html|title=Houston Ballet breaks ground on new downtown home|author=Glentzer, Molly |date=July 31, 2009 |newspaper=[[Houston Chronicle]]|accessdate=2011-05-31}}{{cite web | publisher=[[Houston Ballet]] |title= Houston's New Home for Dance | url= http://www.houstonballet.org/CenterForDance/Houston_Ballet_News_New_Home_For_Dance/|author=Shields, Mitchell J.|year=2009|accessdate=2011-06-28}} However, Gensler has claimed that "'Gensler, not (Strabala), is the source of the architectural and design services rendered in designing Hess Tower'", and that Strabala was but "'one of many members of that Gensler team'" that designed the Houston Ballet Center for Dance. Strabala left Gensler in 2010. ===Formation of new firm=== After leaving Gensler, Strabala started his own [[architectural firm]], 2DEFINE Architecture, with offices in Shanghai, Seoul, and Chicago. According to Strabala, he "continues to be involved in the Shanghai Tower project at the behest of the client". ==Litigation concerning attribution of credit== In June 2011, Gensler, sued Strabala alleging that after founding his own firm he "'misrepresented the nature of his contribution, if any, to certain design projects while intentionally minimizing or entirely omitting the nature of Gensler's contribution.'"{{cite news | title=Architect making false claims, former employer says | url=http://www.wlsam.com/Article.asp?id=2209350&spid= | date=June 10, 2011 | agency=[[Sun-Times Media Wire]] | publisher=[[WLS-AM]] | location=Chicago | accessdate=2011-06-11}}{{cite web|url= http://www.rfcexpress.com/lawsuits/trademark-lawsuits/illinois-northern-district-court/76467/m-arthur-gensler-jr-associates-inc-v-jay-marshall-strabala-individually-and-doing-business-as-2define-architecture/official-court-documents/ | publisher=RFC Express|title=Court Documents|work=Gensler v. Strabala |accessdate=2011-10-19}} One day later, SOM also sued Strabala alleging that he was "falsely claiming credit for work that originated with the company, including the designs for three of the 10 tallest buildings in the world."{{cite news | author=Ugolik, Kaitlin |date= June 10, 2011 | publisher=Law360| title=Ex-Skidmore Architect Sued Over Building Design Claims | url=http://www.law360.com/employment/articles/250517/ex-skidmore-architect-sued-over-building-design-claims | accessdate=2011-06-11 }}{{cite web| url= http://www.rfcexpress.com/lawsuits/copyright-lawsuits/new-york-southern-district-court/76456/skidmore-owings-merrill-llp-v-jay-marshall-strabala/official-court-documents/ | publisher=RFC Express|title=Court Documents|work=Skidmore, Owings and Merrill v. Strabala |accessdate=2011-10-19}} Strabala and his attorneys have filed motions to dismiss both lawsuits.{{cite web |date= Aug. 9, 2011 | title=Motion by Defendant Jay Marshall Strabala to dismiss Pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6) (docket #16) |publisher=[[U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois]] ([[PACER (law)|PACER]]) |work=Gensler v. Strabala ''(1:11-cv-03945)'' | url=https://ecf.ilnd.uscourts.gov/ | accessdate=2011-10-17 }}{{cite web| date= Sep. 12, 2011 | title=Motion to Dismiss for Lack of Jurisdiction filed by Jay Marshall Strabala (docket #17)|work=Skidmore, Owings and Merrill v. Strabala ''(1:11-cv-03906-MGC}}'' |publisher= [[U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York]] ([[PACER (law)|PACER]]) | url=https://ecf.nysd.uscourts.gov/ | accessdate=2011-10-17 }} ==Local involvement== In 1999, Strabala, speaking as a private citizen as part of a community group, testified before the [[Chicago City Council]] Zoning Committee against a high-rise development at 840 [[Lake Shore Drive]] in Chicago, Illinois.{{cite news|title=Streeterville High-rise Passes Zoning Panel | newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] | author=Garza, Melita Marie |date=August 25, 1999 |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1999-08-25/news/9908250257_1_lake-michigan-abrams-soar | accessdate=2011-05-31}} Strabala lived nearby and was concerned that the high-rise would be "out of scale with the neighborhood". Despite opponents' efforts, and that the project would "flout existing law", the Zoning Committee amended the ordinance allowing the project to proceed even though it contradicted zoning ordinances. == References == {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Portal|Biography}} *{{Flickr| id=photos/architectural-design}} *[http://www.define-arch.com/partners.html Strabala's firm profile] {{Persondata |NAME = Strabala, Marshall |ALTERNATIVE NAMES = |SHORT DESCRIPTION = American architect |PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Seattle]], Washington |DATE OF DEATH = |PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Strabala, Marshall}} [[Category:American architects]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:People from Seattle, Washington]] [[Category:University of California, Los Angeles alumni]] [[Category:21st-century architects]] [[Category:Living people]] [[ko:ë§ì ì¤í¸ë¼ë°ë¼]] [[zh:é©¬æ­å°Â·æ¯ç¹æå·´æ]]
